There’s three non-repetitive choruses in the song which is remarkably few in context of rock anthems. Compared to the verses, the melodic phrases are shifted to the right with more of them starting on the downbeat. The harmony of the first phrase is driven by diatonic chains of fifths, especially if we substitute B♭ with its “stand-in” pair G minor. The last phrase is driven by a stepwise ascending line and a static F note in the bassline and various dissonances. Note the chromatic cross-relation: A in the melody, B♭ in the chordal backing.

 The harmony shifts toward the parallel minor key that establishes only after the chorus. Between the last two choruses the tonic of F minor does not appear. The rhythm figure of the last chord nicely resonates with the piano double-accents in the verse and the following instrumental bridge. The second and third chorus adds lead guitar fills, and the last chorus alters the backing rhythm. The song ends with a fermata unresolved on the C7sus4 chord.
[Verse 1]

Verse 1 – 0:00 – 0:33

Verse 2 – 1:17 – 1:49



There are two verses in this song, that are both slightly different. Here’s my analysis of each verse:

Verse 1
The first verse starts with Freddie Mercury on the piano with bass accompaniment. Note the piano accents fall on the 1st and 2nd 1/6 beats in the first and sixth two-measure subphrase while they fall on the 2nd and 3rd beats in the intervening subphrases. This is rhythmically disorienting and may cause 7/8 measures when played not carefully enough. Then re-enters the bass and double-tracked guitars come in, playing antiphonal fills. The bass sustains E♭ as guitar arpeggio’s play E♭sus4 where the piano plays A♭. The music changes to fortissimo, as Roger Taylor enters with the drums and Brian May plays guitar chords with overdriven tone. The last phrase steers the harmony toward F major (the key of the chorus) through B♭ Major. The choir harmonies of the last phrase have a unison upbeat.

Verse 2
The second verse is slightly different then the first. This verse has similar appoggiatura driven static harmonic backing as in the first. The drums are played throughout the section, with hi-hat and cymbal work. Brian’s two track guitar fills underscore perfectly the mood of the section as John Deacon plays melodic treble figures. For the second phrase the bassline gets lower, Roger changes to cymbals and Brian plays the arpeggios familiar from the first verse, but this time with some hocket-like touches added. We then break into the choruses.

“I was thinking about football when I wrote it,” Freddie Mercury told Circus in 1978, when asked about “We Are the Champions.” “I wanted a participation song, something that the fans could latch on to. Of course, I’ve given it more theatrical subtlety than an ordinary football chant.” But for all the inherent grandiosity of Queen’s music and live performances, the rest of the band were taken aback when Freddie first presented them with the song, initially believing that its message was unbecomingly arrogant, even for them. “Our initial sense of it was that it was something very big headed,” May told Guitar World in 2008. “We all looked at Fred and said, ‘Really?’ But he had a very clear view of it. It was aimed at an audience that wanted to feel a togetherness and a power and an optimism. He knew people would sing it.”

“We Are the Champions” has become an anthem for victories at sporting events, including as an official theme song for the 1994 FIFA World Cup, and has been often used or referenced in popular culture.

No time for losers
 ’Cause we are the champions...

A very abrupt ending to the song, as it feels like the next line should be “of the world”, but it never comes.

Naturally, people believe that this ending is an example of the popular Mandela Effect, a phenomenon where people remember events differently from how they really happened, or even events that had never happened to begin with.

Some likely explanations for the collective belief that the song ended with the lines “of the world” is that Mercury may have performed some live shows where he added the line, or that people are just remembering the iconic line in the middle of the song instead.

Regardless, the line is not in any studio recordings of the song, although a majority of clips, including the ones from Big Bang Theory or The Mighty Ducks, use the lyrics in the first chorus and cut the lyrics off there.

This could be seen as being a metaphor for his success. Mercury has had critics who have “kicked him in his face,” but he hasn’t let them affect him. Not only that, but he says that they will keep making music for a long time to come.

“And I need to go on, and on, and on, and on” was the Freddie Mercury original way of writing the lyric.

With all the success they have life still isn’t as sweet as it looks from the outside. There is much sadness and pain that comes with the life they are living that only happens behind closed doors. Especially back then, it was hard for band members to keep in touch with friends and family because they were busy touring.

Freddie is thanking his fans for all of their support over the years. They were the reason he achieved his goals.

I consider it a challenge before the whole human race
 And I ain’t gonna lose

At this point, Freddie Mercury proclaims his greatest ambitions – fame, wealth, and success. This is such a humongous challenge, because getting – worldwide – fame is harder to attain more than anything else. Mercury “won” his fame in 1974 and later on, but “lost” to himself in 1991, of AIDS. And his family lost him.

But what he really wanted to do was far different from the British rock band Queen itself.

According to a 2011 The Telegraph interview with Mercury’s family, at the height of his fame, Mercury wanted nothing more than to sit in the kitchen as his mother cooked for him. His mother said, “He (Freddie Mercury) wanted to be as normal as possible.” Of course, he  missed his family – a lot. So, during his world tours, he “would send postcards from around the world.”



Note the humanist sentiment “before the whole human race”, rather than “before God”, as the ultimate judge of achievement.
